messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:41): ooh. is IE10 PP1 really adding Flexbox? which snapshot of Flexbox?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:43): http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-gb/ie/gg192966#_CSS3FlexBox might or might not say
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:45): Whoa, PP1 already?  They're serious about stepping up their release schedule.
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:46): now if they could just get people off of XP
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:46): Or release their new browsers for XP.
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:47): that takes logic that MS can't compute
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:47): it causes segfaults
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:47): please stop trying to coerce me into "upgrading" away from an OS that I like to one that I do not like; thanks
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (21:47): And here I thought SP3 was their attempt to get people off of XP...
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:47): Do grid and flexbox layouts support very different use-cases?  I thought they were similar ideas.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:48): i don't touch linux as a desktop OS, thanks :P
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:48): relegated to a terminal, where it belongs
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:48): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81, how does that help?  IE doesn't work on Linux either.  :(

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:48): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: They say "Higher cadence just means more frequent releases of incomplete software (and larger version numbers). What matters is when consumers and businesses take delivery of robust, production-ready browsers that use the new technology." which doesn't sound like a great endorsement of a stepped-up release schedule
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (21:49): I have to admit, it's nice to see Microsoft trying to get back into the game.

8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:50): It rather sounds like "It takes us half a year to run all our regression tests by hand, and then another 3 months when we've fixed the regressions, so we can't go faster"
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:51): "it takes a really long time to WONTFIX all of these bug reports"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:52): that there are multiple browsers implementing the same prefixed CSS features is sad. I wish we could get rid of the prefixes faster.
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:52): well you don't need to use them
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, it's been discussed like six times in the CSSWG, and nobody seems to be interested enough to agree on a solution.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17: yes, I do. I want cool stuff right now.

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:53): What they should really do is declare individual features stable even before CR, and commit to not changing the syntax, so that vendors can drop prefixes before the whole spec moves to CR.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:53): having to have bugs like https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=642265 is just sad
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:54): my prefix order is this: -moz, -o, -webkit, no prefix
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:55): i just let IE render what it can, and use modernizr in some cases
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:55): 0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17: why do you discriminate IE?
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:55): because i am not a fan of it at all
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:55): tries to think of common css3-y stuff that uses a -ms- prefix...
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (21:56): historically microsoft has a really well-compressed vendor prefix
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:56): in the past IE has refrained from implementing things with a prefix
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:56): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762, isn't that the consensus?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:56): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: CSS 2D transforms is an example of a spec that's implemented with a prefix in the top 4 engines
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:56): but ie10 changes that philosophy.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:56): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81, possibly, but no one seems to be doing it.
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:56): also 2d transforms in ie9 yes
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:56): 4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049: I count that as a failure of the standardization process
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:57): probably. that and msft is way more "careful" about adopting features than everyone else
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (21:57): MS just marches to the beat of their own drummer and i deal with it last
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:57): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354, just saw your vendor prefix tweet. ace! :D
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:57): I'm not too happy about dropping prefixes before we have a test suite, myself
4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (21:57): "Updated my Vendor Prefixed #CSS overview with lots of new Firefox, Opera and IE hotness :-) http://goo.gl/NZY0N "
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:58): thanks for the copypasta ;)
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:03): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354, i'm not sure about the meaning of gray/italic entries :f
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81, that's a great philosophy if anyone actually bothers writing tests in a reasonable timeframe.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:04): In practice, not so much.
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (22:05): cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb: thanks :) The grey ones are the same properties, yet not prefixed anymore

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:05): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: that doesn't help much if existing content is of the form -moz-foo: bar; -webkit-foo: bar; -o-foo: bar; -ms-foo: bar; foo: bar;
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:06): ah ok... so... firefox supports... filter?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:06): cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb: different filter, IIRC
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:07): https://developer.mozilla.org/en/CSS/filter
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:07): ah yea... svg filter/mask stuff
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:08): Out of curiosity: 'test suite' or 'testsuite'? Both are used on whatwg wiki.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:08): Both are used in my head, too
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:08): 58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354: might make sense to put Firefox's filter and IE's -ms-filter on different rows, since they are really different features
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (22:09): it's a limitation in the system right now, I am aware of the problem
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:10): you could add a tooltip comment for now ;)
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (22:15): i'd use ‚ìò (24d8) instead of that ‚úç thing
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (22:27): cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb: Good idea, thanks! Both changed.
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:39): now we have name collision between IE's filter and modern SVG's filter
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:39): many sites will be broken
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:40): We've had this conflict for forever.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:40): WebKit has even generalized document.all's behaviour for it
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:40): choose for example `svg-filter`
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:41): This hasn't been a problem so far, because IE hasn't implemented SVG 'filter', and the two versions have massively different syntaxes.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:43): "document.all is good" - uh what?
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:44): _filter:alpha(opacity = 50); filter: svg filter here
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea document.all.foo is shorter than document.getElementById('foo')
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:46): Bah.  It should be just query('#foo') (on window, so it can be omitted).
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:47): $ is too opaque, even though it does have a lot of history, imo.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:47): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: Every time you use document.all a kitten dies
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:47): Well I say a kitten
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:48): What's wrong with window.foo? ^_^
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:48): It is more like most of the cute animals for a mile radius
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:49): Hmm, gecko supports that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:49): I'm pretty sure
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:49): Only in quirks mode.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:49): Same as document.all
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:49): (did I already mention that you shouldn't use either?)
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:50): uses window.[id] for quick tests because it's just easier.  Nothing public, though.
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:53): main goal is make development easy imho. foo.onclick = _bar or document.getElementById('foo').addEventListener('click', _bar, false)
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:54): you provide giant stong api with long names
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:54): Yup, most of the "good" APIs were apparently designed with no consideration for authoring ease. :/
f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4 (22:55): ppl are forced to invent jq like frameworks
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:01): f69d55844584e567962289a5226442b4: There is "easy" and "easy to shoot yourself in th foot"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:03): There is also, of course, "omg verbose how did you ever consider this acceptable don't you know we're in Peak ASCII?".
